We have identified a novel annexin, ANX21, in trophozoites of Giardia lamblia. The nucleotide sequence encoding this protein deviated from a published sequence in predicting an additional endonexin fold in the fourth annexin domain. In addition, several motifs exclusively shared by other annexins of G. lamblia in their predicted fourth repeat and predicted to be localized on the opposite (concave) surface of the molecule became apparent. Western blots of trophozoite fractions probed with antiserum against the recombinant protein indicated that this annexin, like the other giardial annexins ANX19 and ANX20, associates with phospholipids in the presence of Ca2+. Finally, confocal laser scanning of trophozoites showed that the protein, apart from the median body, was exclusively localized in the eight flagella. Together, these data suggest that ANX21 may function as a Ca2+-regulated structural element linking phospholipid bilayer and underlying axoneme. We have identified a novel annexin, ANX21, in trophozoites of Giardia lamblia. The nucleotide sequence encoding this protein deviated from a published sequence in predicting an additional endonexin fold in the fourth annexin domain. In addition, several motifs exclusively shared by other annexins of G. lamblia in their predicted fourth repeat and predicted to be localized on the opposite (concave) surface of the molecule became apparent. Western blots of trophozoite fractions probed with antiserum against the recombinant protein indicated that this annexin, like the other giardial annexins ANX19 and ANX20, associates with phospholipids in the presence of Ca2+. Finally, confocal laser scanning of trophozoites showed that the protein, apart from the median body, was exclusively localized in the eight flagella. Together, these data suggest that ANX21 may function as a Ca2+-regulated structural element linking phospholipid bilayer and underlying axoneme. annexin phosphate-buffered saline 3-(cyclohexylamino)propanesulfonic acid trans-epoxysuccinyl-l-leucylamide-(4-guanidino)butane Giardia lamblia (syn. Giardia intestinalis,Giardia duodenalis), a group of diplomonadid parasitic protists, is classified as early branching eukaryotes (1Roger A.J. Amer. Nat. 1999; 154: 146-163Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). G. lamblia occurs throughout the world and triggers a form of diarrhea called giardiasis (2Adam R.D. Clin. Microbiol. Rev. 2001; 14: 447-475Crossref PubMed Scopus (923) Google Scholar). Its life cycle consists of two stages: the infective, immobile cyst form that by virtue of its tough cell wall is able to survive the inhospitable conditions of the host's stomach, and the vegetative, mobile trophozoite form that attaches to the epithelial cells of the gut. It does so with the help of a cytoskeletal structure called ventral disk, which probably functions as a suction cup. The ventral disk consists of spiraling microtubuli with flat structural elements called microribbons protruding from them into the cytoplasm (3Kulda J. Nohýnková E. Kreier J.P. Parasitic Protozoa. 2nd Ed. 10. Academic Press, NY1995: 225-422Crossref Google Scholar). The edges of these microribbons contain two proteins that were originally designated as α-giardins (4Peattie D.A. Alonso R.A. Hein A. Caulfield J.P. J. Cell Biol. 1989; 109: 2323-2335Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 5Alonso R.A. Peattie D.A. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1992; 50: 95-104Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar) and shown to be associated with the cytoskeletal fraction by detergent extraction of the insoluble cell pellet (6Crossley R. Holberton D. J. Cell Sci. 1985; 78: 205-231PubMed Google Scholar). Based on their predicted amino acid sequence, they were later identified as members (ANX19 and ANX20) of the annexin (ANX)1 family (7Morgan O.R. Fernandez M.-P. Mol. Biol. Evol. 1995; 12: 967-979PubMed Google Scholar). Annexins are eukaryotic proteins that usually bind to phospholipid bilayers in a Ca2+-dependent manner (for an exception, see Ref. 8Jost M. Zeuschner D. Seemann J. Weber K. Gerke V. J. Cell Sci. 1997; 110: 221-228Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and supposedly play a role in Ca2+-dependent membrane dynamics (9Gerke V. Moss E.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1357: 129-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar). They consist of four homologous, mainly α-helical domains folded into a concave/convex shape. In annexins of higher eukaryotes, each of these four domains possesses the canonical repeat GXGTD followed by an aspartate or glutamate residue 38 positions downstream that forms a loop (AB loop) at the convex surface and functions as high affinity (“type II”) Ca2+-binding site (10Seaton B.A. Annexins: Molecular Structure to Cellular Function. Springer-Verlag New York Inc., New York1996: 15-29Google Scholar). Other Ca2+-binding sites with lower affinity (“type III”) provided by spatially clustered carboxylate groups are likewise positioned at the convex surface of the molecule. Most annexins exhibit an ion channel activity with ion transport assumed to occur through a central pore lined by charged residues, particularly glutamate and arginine (9Gerke V. Moss E.S. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1997; 1357: 129-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (320) Google Scholar). Although the giardial annexins ANX19 (11Bauer B. Engelbrecht S. Bakker-Grunwald T. Scholze H. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1999; 173: 147-153PubMed Google Scholar) and ANX20, 2M. Hauptmann, unpublished data. in addition to interacting with the cytoskeleton fraction (6Crossley R. Holberton D. J. Cell Sci. 1985; 78: 205-231PubMed Google Scholar, 12Peattie D.A. Parasitol. Today. 1990; 6: 52-56Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar), bind to phospholipids in a Ca2+-dependent manner, they lack an endonexin fold and do not exhibit ion channel activity. In a report on the structure of a gene encoding a pyruvate-ferredoxin oxidoreductase from G. lamblia, a flanking complementary DNA sequence putatively encoding an additional annexin has been identified (13Townson S.M. Upcroft J.A. Upcroft P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 79: 183-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). To extend the open reading frame and to increase the overall similarity of the predicted ANX21 to other annexins, the authors postulated an insert of an undefined nucleotide at position 9846 of the complementary sequence (14Morgan R.O. Pilar Fernandez M. J. Mol. Evol. 1997; 44: 178-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). We here present a corrected nucleotide sequence predicting a protein with, in its fourth domain, a bona fide endonexin fold on its convex surface and conserved giardin motifs on its concave surface. In trophozoites, ANX21 was exclusively localized in the flagella. These data are consistent with a model in which ANX21 functions as a Ca2+-regulated structural element linking the flagellar membrane and the axoneme. Trophozoites of G. lamblia strain WB-C6 (ATCC 30957) were cultured in Keister's modified TYI-S-33 medium (15Keister D.B. Trans. R. Soc. Trop. Med. Hyg. 1983; 77: 487-488Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (798) Google Scholar). Cells were harvested at the end of the logarithmic phase (after 3–4 days), washed three times in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS; 150 mm NaCl, 20 mm K2HPO4, 7.5 mm KH2PO4, pH 6.9), and stored at −20 °C in the presence of 10 μm (final concentration)trans-epoxysuccinyl-l-leucylamide- (4-guanidino)butane (E-64), a potent inhibitor of cysteine proteinases. Genomic DNA was isolated from fresh trophozoites using an Elu-Quick kit (Schleicher and Schuell). To amplify the open reading frame flanking that of the pyruvate-ferredoxin oxidoreductase (13Townson S.M. Upcroft J.A. Upcroft P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 79: 183-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar), which has been predicted to code for an annexin homologue (14Morgan R.O. Pilar Fernandez M. J. Mol. Evol. 1997; 44: 178-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), we constructed the following synthetic oligonucleotide primers (bold, restriction sites for BamH1): 5′-GTTTTTGTGACACTCGAGAGTAAAATGGC-3′ (C1anx21) and 5′-GAATTATTTACACGACTACAACTCGAGAG-3′ (C2anx21). This primer pair frames the full open reading frame from position 318 to 1369 of the DNA sequence deposited in the sequence data base (GenBankTML17221). PCR on genomic DNA as template was performed using Pfu-polymerase (Stratagene, Heidelberg). The PCR profile was as follows: 5 min at 94 °C, 45 cycles with 2 min at 55 °C, 2 min at 72 °C, and 1 min at 94 °C, then 2 min at 55 °C, and 5 min at 72 °C. The amplification product was purified using a QIAEx-II-Gel-Extraction-Kit (Qiagen, Hilden Germany) according to the instructions of the manufacturer, subcloned into pBSK, and sequenced by the automated dideoxy chain termination method (MWG Biotech and in house). The sequence was determined twice in both directions. The amplification product was digested withBamH1 and ligated in frame into the multiple cloning site of the expression vector pET16b, which contains a 5′-extension sequence coding for 10 histidine residues (“His-tag”). After transfection of the construct into Escherichia coli BL21 and induction with isopropyl-1-thio-β-d-galactopyranoside, the overproduced protein product was partially present in the soluble fraction as checked by SDS-PAGE. For purification, the soluble E. coliextract was adjusted to 25 mm imidazole, the mixture applied onto a Ni-NTA column, and the recombinant protein eluted with 20 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.9, containing 250 mmimidazole. This yielded a >95% pure recombinant protein judging from SDS-PAGE (data not shown), which was sent out for the immunization of rabbits (Eurogentec, Belgium). On a Western blot of an extract ofE. coli containing the recombinant protein and of the purified recombinant protein, the antiserum (1:1000) reacted with a single protein band at an apparent M r 40,500; the same band was detected with antipenta-His antiserum (Qiagen, 1:2000; data not shown). Annexins were isolated from crude trophozoite homogenates by EGTA extraction according to Ref. 16Boustead C.M. Walker J.H. Geisow M.J. FEBS Lett. 1988; 233: 233-238Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar. Pellet and supernatant fractions were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. For phospholipid binding, 400 μl of 20 mm Hepes brought to pH 7.4 with NaOH containing 100 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, and 0.5 mg multilamellar liposomes (brain extract; Sigma) was added to 100 μl of soluble EGTA extract containing 30 μg of protein. The mixture was incubated for 40 min at room temperature under shaking and then centrifuged for 10 min at 15,000 ×g. In a parallel experiment, the free Ca2+concentration in the mixture was adjusted to 1 mm, and in control incubations the brain extract was omitted. For isolation of detergent-insoluble cytoskeletal proteins cells were homogenized in the presence of 4 mm Ca2+, the homogenate was centrifuged for 10 min at 15,000 × g, and the pellet fraction subsequently was extracted with 0.5% (w/v) Triton X-100. The extract was mixed with an equal volume of ice-cold 10% (w/v) trichloroacetic acid, and equivalent fractions of the precipitated protein (Triton X-100 extract) and the Triton-insoluble pellet were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. Trophozoite flagella were isolated by the method of Clark and Holberton (17Clark J.T. Holberton D.V. Parasitol. Res. 1988; 74: 415-423Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar). Briefly, the cells were washed twice by centrifugation in 0.25 m sucrose and resuspended in TMSK buffer consisting of 30 mm Tris, 2.5 mmMgSO4, 0.2 m sucrose, 25 mm KCl, 1 μm E-64, and 0.005% (w/v) phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, pH 7.4. The suspension was homogenized for 1 min with an Ultra-Turrax (Braun Melsungen, Germany). Cell bodies were removed by centrifuging for 10 min at 220 × g in a swingout rotor. The flagella, which were contained in the supernatant, were pelleted at 13,000 × g for 20 min and purified by density gradient centrifugation through a self-forming Percoll gradient. To this end, the crude flagellar fraction was mixed with 10 ml of 40% (v/v) Percoll (Amersham Biosciences) in TMSK buffer and centrifuged for 60 min at 48,000 × g. For calibration, a parallel gradient was run with Percoll density marker beads. Fractions containing flagella (density range between 1.09 and 1.11 g/ml) were diluted with TMSK, and the flagella were pelleted for 5 min at 13,000 ×g and analyzed by Western blotting. SDS-PAGE was performed in the Tris/glycine system of Douglas et al. (18Douglas M. Finkelstein D. Butow R.A. Methods Enzymol. 1979; 56: 58-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar) using 10% gels. Proteins were visualized by dispersion staining with Coomassie Brilliant Blue G-250 (19Neuhoff V. Arold N. Taube D. Ehrhardt W. Electrophoresis. 1988; 88: 255-262Crossref Scopus (2356) Google Scholar). Western blotting onto nitrocellulose membranes was performed according to Ref. 20Matsudaira P J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 10035-10038Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar in a CAPS/NaOH-buffer, pH 11.0, containing 10% methanol. For immune decoration of the blots, rabbit antiserum against recombinant ANX21 was used in a dilution of 1:1000. As secondary antibodies we used goat anti-rabbit IgG (Pierce; 1:2,000) coupled to peroxidase, and as chromogenic substrate, we used 4-chloro-1-naphthol. Trophozoites were allowed to attach to coverslips at 37 °C, fixed for 7 min with methanol, and permeabilized for 5 min with acetone, both at −20 °C (21Nohynková E. Dráber P. Reischig J. Kulda J. Eur. J. Cell Biol. 2000; 79: 438-445Crossref PubMed Scopus (47) Google Scholar). After rehydrating with PBS for 10 min at room temperature, the cells were incubated with blocking buffer (3% fetal porcine serum in PBS) for 10 min and then were reacted for 1 h with the rabbit anti-ANX21 antiserum (1:10,000 in PBS). After washing three times with PBS the cells were incubated for 1 h in the dark with CY3TM-conjugated anti-rabbit F(ab)2 fragment from sheep (Sigma; 1:100 in PBS) as secondary antibody. As a positive control cells were labeled with a monoclonal antibody against antiacetylated tubulin (mouse IgG2b isotype from Sigma, 1:2000 in PBS) followed by anti-mouse IgG CY3 conjugate F(ab)2 fragment from sheep (Sigma; 1:400 in PBS). After another three washes with PBS the cells were analyzed in a confocal laser scanning microscope (Zeiss cLSM 410) equipped with an Ar/Kr excitation laser at 568 nm and an emission filter for 590 nm. To check for the postulated insertion of an undefined nucleotide (14Morgan R.O. Pilar Fernandez M. J. Mol. Evol. 1997; 44: 178-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar) in the published sequence of anx21 (13Townson S.M. Upcroft J.A. Upcroft P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 79: 183-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar) and to pinpoint its nature and exact position we amplified the complete open reading frame using genomic DNA as template and sequenced the amplified product (sequence available from the EMBL data base under the accession number AJ271737). While confirming an insert of one base (identified as G), we found its exact position to occur at nucleotide number 9836 rather than 9846, as proposed by Morgan and Fernandez (14Morgan R.O. Pilar Fernandez M. J. Mol. Evol. 1997; 44: 178-188Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar), of the complementary sequence. This correction of the published nucleotide sequence increases the identity of the second half of the sequence to that of giardial ANX19–20 from 14 to 19% and to that of human ANX5 (22Grundmann U. Abel K.-J. Bohn H. Loebermann H. Lottspeich F. Kuepper H. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 3708-3712Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar) from 11 to 19% and reveals an additional endonexin fold (GSGSD{38}E) at positions 257–261 and 299 (Fig.1; numbering adapted to ANX5 sequence). Moreover, the corrected predicted C-terminal sequence now shares several sequence motifs with ANX19 and ANX20, namely IT(G/A)M at 268–270 and 272, KXXYK (X stands for a variable residue) at 281–285, DXER at 293–296 and Trp at 311 (Fig. 1). (Some of these residues have been boxed as “protist-specific” in Ref. 13Townson S.M. Upcroft J.A. Upcroft P. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 1996; 79: 183-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar, Fig. 6). Meanwhile, the genome data base of G. lamblia (23McArthur A.G. Morrison H.G. Nixon J.E. Passamaneck N.Q. Kim U. Hinkle G. Crocker M.K. Holder M.E. Farr R. Reich C.I. Olsen G.E. Aley S.B. Adam R.D. Gillin F.D. Sogin M.L. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 2000; 189: 271-273Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) has yielded ≥13 other independent sequences encoding putative annexins, and strikingly, all of these are predicted to exhibit the four motifs common to ANX19–21 (but not the endonexin fold shared by ANX21 and ANX5; data not shown), whereas these motifs fail in all known annexins from other organisms. In most of these sequences a positively charged residue (usually Arg) follows the tryptophan residue at 311. In a molecular model the indole ring of this tryptophan together with the KXXYK motif ends up on the concave surface of the molecule, opposite the endonexin fold (Fig.2), suggesting that these residues could constitute a binding site for a cytoplasmic interaction partner.Figure 2Molecular model of ANX21. The model was computed by the SWISS-MODEL program (31Guex N. Peitsch M.C. Electrophoresis. 1997; 18: 2714-2723Crossref PubMed Scopus (9640) Google Scholar) using the coordinates of related annexins and visualized with the WebLabViewer. The fourth domain is marked in dark gray. G. lamblia-specific residues on the concave side of the molecule are labeled. The fourth-domain endonexin fold comprises an extended loop on the convex side of the molecule.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Both Southern blot analysis and data base searching indicated that theG. lamblia genome possesses just one nucleotide sequence encoding ANX21 (data not shown). Northern blot analysis confirmed expression of this anx21 gene in trophozoites with a transcript size (∼1050 nt) that leaves ∼40 nt for the 5′- and 3′-untranslated regions (Fig. 3). To raise anti-ANX21 antibodies we overproduced the recombinant, His-tagged protein heterologously in E. coli (for details, see “Experimental Procedures”). Probing of Western blots with the antiserum raised against the recombinant protein confirmed that ANX21 is present in trophozoites (Fig. 4).Figure 4Phospholipid binding of trophozoite ANX21 and its association with the detergent-insoluble cytoskeletal fraction. A, phospholipid binding of ANX21 obtained by EGTA extraction of crude trophozoite homogenate. Multilamellar liposomes prepared from brain extract phospholipids were added in the absence (lanes 1–2) or presence (lanes 3–4) of 1 mm free Ca2+; the supernatant (s) and pellet (p) fractions were subjected to SDS-PAGE, blotted, and probed with anti-ANX21 antiserum. Lanes 5–6show control without phospholipids. B, association of ANX21 with the detergent-insoluble fraction. A crude trophozoite homogenate prepared in the presence of 4 mm free Ca2+either without detergent (lanes 1–2) or after subsequent extraction with Triton X-100 (lanes 3–4) was fractionated into supernatant (s) and pellet (p) fractions and probed as above. Lane 5 shows EGTA extract of pellet fromlane 4. Each lane contained 30 μg of protein. For further details, see “Experimental Procedures.”View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To investigate the association of ANX21 with negatively charged phospholipids, we extracted trophozoite homogenate with EGTA and incubated the soluble supernatant with multilamellar liposomes prepared from brain extract. Fig. 4 A shows that the extracted ANX21, just like ANX19 (11Bauer B. Engelbrecht S. Bakker-Grunwald T. Scholze H. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1999; 173: 147-153PubMed Google Scholar) and ANX 20 (data not shown), ended up in the pellet fraction in the presence of excess Ca2+ (lane 4) but remained in the supernatant in its absence (lane 1). This effect was strictly dependent on the presence of the liposomes (lanes 5–6). These data confirm that ANX21 behaves as a classical annexin in associating with negatively charged phospholipids in a Ca2+-dependent way. In a complementary set of experiments, we homogenized the cells in the presence of free Ca2+. As expected, in the presence of endogenous phospholipids, ANX21 remained in the insoluble fraction (lane 2 of Fig. 4 B). Likewise, when the pellet fraction was subsequently extracted with detergent, ANX21 remained in the pellet fraction (Fig. 4 B, lane 4). However, when this pellet was treated with an 1 mm excess of EGTA, ANX21 went into solution (lane 5, Fig. 4 B). As any phospholipid membranes that had been precipitated from the homogenate should be dissolved into floating micellar structures by the detergent, we interpret these data to mean that ANX21, apart from binding to phospholipids, also associates with detergent-insoluble cytoskeletal elements in the presence of Ca2+. An association with the detergent-extracted cytoskeletal fraction has also been reported (17Clark J.T. Holberton D.V. Parasitol. Res. 1988; 74: 415-423Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar) for ANX19 and ANX20 (at that time denoted as α-giardins). Combining the model of Fig. 2 with the fractionation behavior documented in Fig.4, we speculate that the G. lamblia-specific motifs of ANX19–21 are responsible for interaction (directly or indirectly) with detergent-insoluble cytoskeletal elements. In fixed and permeabilized trophozoites, ANX21 was exclusively localized in the eight flagella (and in those cells where it was observable, in the median body) (Fig. 5 A). Control incubations with antisera against tubulin (Fig. 5 B) and a proteasome subunit (not shown) indicated that this restricted distribution was not due to a lack of permeability of the cells. In agreement with these data, Western blot analysis of isolated flagella revealed cross-reaction with both the tubulin and ANX21 antibodies (Fig. 5 C) but not with anti-ANX19 antibodies (data not shown). Together with our observation that ANX21 interacts with both phospholipids and the detergent-insoluble cytoskeletal fraction in a Ca2+-dependent way, we interpret the flagellar localization to mean that ANX21 may play a Ca2+-regulated structural role in trophozoite motility. Specifically, our data would fit in with a model in which binding of Ca2+ to the convex surface of ANX21, apart from increasing the affinity of this surface to the flagellar membrane, induces a conformational change at the concave surface that enables the latter to interact with a cytoskeletal element of the axoneme (possibly an adapter protein). In the literature, there are precedents for both Ca2+-dependent binding of annexins to cytoskeletal proteins and for the localization of annexins in flagella or cilia. Thus, many vertebrate annexins bind F-actin in a Ca2+-dependent way (24Khanna N.C. Helwig E.D. Ikebuchi N.W. Fitzpatrick S. Bajwa R. Waisman D.M. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 4852-4862Crossref PubMed Scopus (66) Google Scholar). For ANX2, this binding has been shown to depend upon the nine C-terminal amino acid residues that, just like the motifs specifically shared by the annexins of G. lamblia (Fig. 2), are predicted to be located on the concave surface of the protein (25Filipenko N.R. Waisman D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 5310-5315Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (108) Google Scholar). (The F-actin-binding ANX2 residues are not conserved in the G. lamblia annexins; data not shown). As to axonemal localization, the ciliated cells of lung epithelium specifically contain ANX1 in their cilia (26Mayran N. Traverso V. Maroux S. Massey-Harroche D. Am. J. Physiol. 1996; 270: 863-871PubMed Google Scholar), and both ANX1 and ANX2 have been found to move to the sperm flagellum during ram sperm maturation (27Feinberg J.M. Rainteau D.P. Kaetzel M.A. Dacheux J.L. Dedman J.R. Weinman S.J. J. Histochem. Cytochem. 1991; 39: 955-963Crossref PubMed Scopus (23) Google Scholar). An interesting variant on the theme of association of Ca2+-regulated proteins with axonemes is provided by the paraflagellar rod complex from Trypanosoma brucei, which instead of annexins, contains EF-hand Ca2+-binding proteins (28Wu Y. Haghighat N.G. Ruben L. Biochem. J. 1992; 287: 187-193Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar, 29Ridgley E. Webster P. Patton C. Ruben L. Mol. Biochem. Parasitol. 2000; 109: 195-201Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). As mentioned above, we hypothesize that for Ca2+-dependent interaction of ANX21 with theG. lamblia axoneme the four motifs conserved in the last domains of giardial annexins (Fig. 1) may be important; consequently, our future experiments will be directed at identifying the corresponding protein binding partner(s) of these annexins. We thank Bettina Flockenhaus for expert technical advice and Dr. Tilly Bakker-Grunwald for constructive criticism of the manuscript.

A model system to examine the expression and antiviral activity of trans-acting ribozymes in mammalian cells has been developed and evaluated. Hairpin ribozymes were engineered to cleave a specific site, identified by a combinatorial activity-based selection method, within genomic and subgenomic RNA species of Sindbis virus. Transiently transfected cells expressed moderate levels of ribozyme (∼50,000 molecules/cell) with predominant nuclear localization and a short half-life (23 min). Stable cell lines expressed ribozymes at modest levels (∼2,000 molecules/cell). Ribozyme-mediated RNA cleavage activity was detected in cell extracts. Clonal cell lines were challenged with recombinant Sindbis virus, and viral replication was examined using plaque formation and green fluorescent protein assays. Significant inhibition of viral replication was observed in cells expressing the active antiviral ribozyme, and lower levels of inhibition in control cells expressing inactive or irrelevant ribozymes. These findings are consistent with a model in which inhibition of viral replication occurs via ribozyme cleavage of viral RNAs, suggesting that ribozymes may represent useful antiviral agents. Virol. 1999; 73: 5381-5387Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) have described attempts to achieve ribozyme inhibition of viral replication, but success has been limited. In some cases, there remains uncertainty as to whether viral inhibition results from ribozyme cleavage of the targeted RNA, because other mechanisms of inhibition, such as antisense effects and interference with the expression of cellular genes that support viral replication, have not always been ruled out. Nucleic Acids Res. 1998; 26: 3494-3504Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar) and in trans (9Vitiello D. Pecchia D. Burke J.M. RNA. 2000; 6: 628-637Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). These studies were undertaken systematically to monitor intracellular ribozyme-mediated RNA cleavage and were accompanied by controls that included inactive ribozyme, uncleavable substrates, and active ribozymes with irrelevant substrate specificity. We concluded that the intracellular selectivity and biochemical requirements of the hairpin ribozyme appear to parallel closely those that have been elucidated in the test tube. The same conclusion has recently been shown to be true for cleavage and ligation of the hairpin ribozyme in yeast (10Deleted in proofGoogle Scholar, 11Yadava R.S. Choi A.J. Lebruska L.L. Fedor M.J. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 309: 893-902Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar, 12Donahue C.P. Yadava R.S. Nesbitt S.M. Fedor M.J. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 295: 693-707Crossref Scopus (44) Google Scholar). To examine the issue of target site specificity, we conducted a comprehensive survey of ribozyme cleavage sites within a highly structured RNA, the 26 S subgenomic RNA of Sindbis virus, using a combinatorial method in which cleavage sites were mapped using a library of hairpin ribozymes containing all possible substrate specificities (13Yu Q. Pecchia D.B. Kingsley S.L. Heckman J.E. Burke J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 23524-23533Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). This method was compared with the standard method of site selection, the identification of sites that most closely fit the substrate consensus sequence, established by in vitro studies employing oligoribonucleotide substrates (14Yu Q. Burke J.M. Methods Mol. Biol. 1997; 74: 161-169PubMed Google Scholar). Strikingly, nearly all sites that were cleaved most effectively by the ribozyme library showed marked deviation from the established consensus sequence. Comparative in vitro cleavage analysis using synthetic ribozymes directed to both consensus and non-consensus sites showed that the “activity-selected” non-consensus ribozymes cleaved structured target RNA molecules slowly but much more effectively than did ribozymes directed to consensus or “sequence-selected” sites. However, the latter class was significantly more effective in cleaving oligoribonucleotide substrates. Together, these results support a model in which target site accessibility is essential for cleavage, whereas correspondence to the preferred substrate sequence is of secondary importance (13Yu Q. Pecchia D.B. Kingsley S.L. Heckman J.E. Burke J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 23524-23533Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Sindbis virus is a member of the Alphavirus genus, a group of arthropod-borne enveloped viruses that cause acute encephalitis and arthritis in humans and animals (15Strauss J.H. Strauss E.G. Microbiol. Rev. 1994; 58: 491-562Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The 11,703-nucleotide positive strand RNA genome of Sindbis virus strain S.A.A.R.86 (16Simpson D.A. Davis N.L. Lin S.C. Russell D. Johnston R.E. Virology. 1996; 222: 464-469Crossref PubMed Scopus (52) Google Scholar) is capped, polyadenylated, and infectious. Translation of the 49 S genomic RNA is followed by proteolytic processing, generating proteins nsP1–nsP4, which are responsible for cytoplasmic RNA synthesis. Production of positive and negative strand genomic RNA begins during the first 3 h of infection and reaches a plateau by 24 h. Large quantities of a 26 S subgenomic RNA are generated, leading to the recruitment of essentially all of the ribosomes of the host cell for synthesis of the viral structural proteins. Infectious virions are released from the cell membrane at a prodigious rate (2000 plaque-forming units/h). Infection is characterized by dramatic cytopathology and induced apoptosis within 36 h after infection. Because of its rapid replication, large burst size, and highly structured RNA, Sindbis virus represents a highly challenging system in which to develop and test antiviral ribozymes. Here, we report that the expression of hairpin ribozymes within clonal cell lines can effectively and selectively inhibit the replication of Sindbis virus. Coverslips were stored in 70% ethanol at 4 °C until ready for hybridization. Hybridization reactions were performed as follows. Cells were washed two times for 5 min in 1× phosphate-buffered saline (PBS),1 two times for 5 min in 100 mm glycine in 1× PBS, 15 min in 0.3% Triton X-100, and two times in 1× PBS. Cells were permeabilized by treatment with 1 ng of proteinase K in Tris/EDTA, pH 8.0, at 37 °C for 5 min. Cells were then post-fixed in 4% formaldehyde, 1× PBS for 5 min at 4 °C, washed two times in 1× PBS and two times for 5 min in 100 mm triethanolamine, pH 8.0, and 0.25% acetic anhydride at 37 °C. Viruses were allowed to adsorb to cells for 1 h at 37 °C. The inoculum was removed, and cells were overlaid with 0.5% agarose in complete medium and further incubated for 36 h at 37 °C. The agarose overlay was removed, and cells were stained with 1% crystal violet solution. Plates were scored for the total number of plaques formed to calculate plaque-forming units/ml. Cells were infected with Sindbis-GFP virus as described above at an m.o.i. of 0.3 and analyzed for GFP expression 24 h after infection. Monolayers of cells were harvested by trypsinization, fixed with formalin, and scored by single channel fluorescence in a flow cytometer (Coulter EPICS Elite) to examine GFP emission (488 nm excitation, and 530 ± 30 nm emission). Ten thousand cells were analyzed per sample. Subsequent analysis of flow cytometry data was performed using WinList 3D curve-fitting software (Verity Software House, Topsham, ME). Resolution of the GFP positive peaks of the cell population was determined using the negative subtraction option in the software. This analysis technique automatically subtracts the negative control data from the actual sample data, leaving the positive fraction for statistical analysis. This technique is most often used when attempting to discern mixed peaks. Two 5′-32P-labeled primers were used simultaneously in primer extension reactions: a ribozyme-specific primer that is complementary to the loop B domain (5′-CCAGGTAATGTACGATCTC-3′) and yields an 88-nucleotide long extension product from the ribozyme transcript driven by the U6 promoter; and a U6 snRNA-specific primer that is complementary to native U6 snRNA (5′-GGCCATGCTAATCTTCTCTG-3′) and generates a 61-nucleotide extension product, which was used as an internal control. Purified cellular RNA (5 μg) was first denatured in the presence of 5′-32P-labeled DNA primers (4 × 105 dpm, 50 fmol) at 80 °C for 10 min in 5 μl of hybridization buffer (60 mm NaCl, 50 mmTris·HCl pH 7.5, 5 mm dithiothreitol) and then slowly cooled to 30 °C to permit annealing. Annealed samples (2 μl) were added to 3 μl of primer extension buffer (0.375 mm dNTPs, 1× hybridization buffer). Reverse transcription was initiated by adding MgCl2 to 4 mm and 5 units of avian myeloblastosis virus (AMV) reverse transcriptase followed by a 30-min incubation at 47 °C. Reactions were quenched by the addition of an equal volume of formamide loading buffer containing 10 mm EDTA, denatured at 80 °C for 2 min, and then separated by electrophoresis through an 8% denaturing polyacrylamide sequencing gel. Gels were quantified using a Bio-Rad GS-525 molecular imager and Molecular Analyst 2.1 software. Cell Res. 1988; 176: 344-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). The ribozyme expression constructs employ a U6 snRNA expression strategy (21Good P.D. Krikos A.J., Li, S.X. Bertrand E. Lee N.S. Giver L. Ellington A. Zaia J.A. Rossi J.J. Engelke D.R. Gene Ther. 1997; 4: 45-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar) and lead to the synthesis of RNA transcripts containing 5′- and 3′-terminal flanking sequences (Fig.1) that are intended to (i) promote the initiation and termination of discrete ribozyme-containing transcripts, (ii) isolate the ribozyme within a discrete RNA folding domain, and (iii) stabilize the transcript from exonucleolytic degradation. The effects of these additional sequences on the catalytic activity of the ribozyme were determined by kinetic analysis under single turnover conditions in vitro. The observed cleavage rate (0.034 min−1) is within a factor of 3 of that observed under the same conditions for a ribozyme transcript that lacks flanking sequences. Importantly, the extent of cleavage is high (90% cleavage after 80 min; data not shown). Together, the high extent of cleavage and the modest decline in cleavage rate induced by the flanking sequences were judged to be satisfactory for proceeding with cellular expression and viral inhibition assays. BHK-21 cells were transfected with plasmids encoding ribozymes, and both transiently transfected populations and stably transfected clonal cell lines were derived. To measure the accumulation of ribozyme-containing transcripts, total cellular RNA was harvested as a function of time after transfection, and a quantitative primer extension assay was employed using two 32P-labeled primers, one specific for the hairpin ribozyme and the other for U6 snRNA. Ribozyme transcripts accumulated to relatively high levels (5 × 104/cell) in transiently transfected cells. Stable cell lines showed significantly lower accumulation (2 × 103/cell), consistent with a lower copy number. Detectable levels of transcript could be identified as early as 5 h after transfection, and peak levels of ribozyme accumulation were observed at 24–30 h in transient populations (data not shown). In situ hybridization of transiently transfected cells revealed predominant nuclear localization of the ribozyme transcripts (Fig. 2) consistent with published results (21Good P.D. Krikos A.J., Li, S.X. Bertrand E. Lee N.S. Giver L. Ellington A. Zaia J.A. Rossi J.J. Engelke D.R. Gene Ther. 1997; 4: 45-54Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar, 22Bertrand E. Castanotto D. Zhou C. Carbonnelle C. Lee N.S. Good P. Chatterjee S. Grange T. Pictet R. Kohn D. Engelke D. Rossi J.J. RNA. 1997; 3: 75-88PubMed Google Scholar). However, there does appear to be a fluorescent signal above background in the cytoplasm of cells probed with antisense ribozyme probe. No hybridization signal was observed when stable cell lines were used, consistent with the decreased steady state accumulation of ribozyme transcripts in the cell lines. The stability of ribozyme transcripts and native U6 snRNA were measured by primer extension experiments following transcriptional arrest of both transiently and stably transfected clonal cells by actinomycin D (Fig. 3). The half-life of the ribozyme transcript (23 min) was much shorter than that of U6 snRNA (20 h) (27Sauterer R.A. Feeney R.J. Zieve G.W. Exp. Cell Res. 1988; 176: 344-359Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar,28Terns M. Dahlberg J. Lund E. Genes Dev. 1993; 7: 1898-1908Crossref PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar). The activity of ribozymes expressed within BHK-21 cells was confirmed by assaying cleavage activity in extracts of total cellular RNA. Cleavage reactions were carried out using 32P end-labeled substrate (1.5 nm) in molar excess over expressed ribozymes (0.16 nm). RNA extracted from cells expressing the active ribozyme cleaved the substrate, whereas no cleavage was observed when RNA was prepared from untransfected cells or cells that express the mutationally inactivated ribozyme (Fig.4). These results demonstrate that (i) cellular transcripts of the active ribozyme have the desired trans-cleavage activity and specificity, (ii) the mutations eliminate cleavage activity in these transcripts, (iii) the ribozyme can find its substrate within the highly complex population of cellular RNA, and (iv) no endogenous cellular RNA can cleave the Sindbis 8242 target. Ribozyme inhibition of viral replication was examined by viral challenge of stable cell lines expressing hairpin ribozymes. The two assays of Sindbis virus replication employed to monitor virus production by ribozyme-expressing cell lines were plaque formation and GFP expression. These assays were conducted in parallel. BHK-21 cells and cells expressing the active antiviral ribozyme, inactive antiviral ribozyme, and active ribozyme with an altered (irrelevant) target specificity were infected with recombinant Sindbis virus at an m.o.i. of 0.05. Aliquots of the supernatant were removed from cultures at time points from 24 to 48 h after infection and then assayed for plaque formation by plating on BHK-21 cells. Cells were exposed to infectious virus in duplicate, using two culture dishes for each time point of each assay. Results show nearly confluent formation of plaques when viruses obtained from a 36-h infection of control BHK-21 cells were plated (Fig. 5, panel IC). In contrast, cells expressing the active antiviral ribozyme generated far fewer infectious virions (Fig. 5, panel A). The elimination of catalytic activity via mutations in the catalytic core of the ribozyme greatly diminished the antiviral activity (Fig. 5, panel I). The active ribozyme with an altered target specificity showed some inhibition of viral replication (Fig. 5, panel M), although the extent of inhibition was markedly less than that for cells expressing the active antiviral ribozyme. The time course shows that these trends hold for all time points after the emergence of infectious viral particles (Fig. 5). Separate aliquots of supernatants from infected cell lines were used to infect BHK-21 cells at an m.o.i. of 0.3. Cells were fixed for analysis by flow cytometry 24 h after the start of infection (Fig.6). In this assay, GFP synthesis serves as a surrogate reporter for viral gene expression. At all time points after infection, GFP expression from viruses grown in cells expressing the active antiviral ribozyme was strongly inhibited, whereas expression from viruses grown in control cells not expressing ribozyme was high. Expression of the catalytically inactive ribozyme resulted in a modest decrease in GFP expression, but the extent of inhibition was significantly less than that observed for the active antiviral ribozyme. Expression of the active ribozyme with altered target specificity resulted in little diminution of GFP expression. Our results strongly support a model in which the expression of hairpin ribozymes directed against a target site in Sindbis virus genomic and subgenomic RNA molecules inhibits viral replication through a targeted RNA cleavage mechanism. The expression of control ribozymes that lack catalytic activity or have irrelevant target specificities results in little inhibitory activity, supporting the conclusion that antisense and nonspecific mechanisms of viral inhibition are significantly less important than targeted RNA cleavage. The agreement of data sets obtained from two independent and quantitative methods for monitoring viral replication and gene expression provides additional confidence in these results. Although these results are consistent with cleavage of the targeted site (nucleotide position 8242) within viral RNA molecules, they do not themselves prove that viral inhibition results from cleavage of the intended site. For example, inhibition by ribozyme 8242 could result from cleavage of an unintended site within the viral RNA or from cleavage of a mRNA encoding a host gene product necessary for viral replication. Conclusions regarding the site of action can come only from mutational analysis of the target site. These studies are now underway in our laboratory. The observed level of antiviral activity is less than profound. However, it should be noted that there are three factors that may have significantly limited the antiviral activity of the ribozyme used in this work. First, the clonal cell lines employed in our viral inhibition experiments express ribozymes at low steady state levels. Second, Sindbis virus replicates rapidly and produces progeny viruses at a very high rate (∼2000 viruses/cell/h). Up to 200,000 copies of the subgenomic RNA can be made in a single cell (29Wengler G. Schlesinger R.W. The Togaviruses. Academic Press, New York1980: 459Crossref Google Scholar). Therefore, viral replication, once established in a cell, would be expected to overwhelm the ribozymes. Third, the ribozymes show predominant (but not exclusive) nuclear localization, whereas viral replication occurs within the cytoplasm. It should be noted that the sensitivity of the in situhybridization experiments was insufficient to observe ribozymes expressed in the stable cell lines used for the viral challenge experiments. Therefore, it is possible that the subcellular distribution of ribozymes expressed at low levels might be different from that observed when ribozymes are expressed at higher levels. Specifically, the high expression levels in transiently transfected cells may saturate a nuclear export system. In addition, it is possible that other target sites may be identified that can be cleaved with higher efficiency. In this regard, it should be noted that target sites have been identified that can be cleaved with higher efficiency than the 8242 site used in the present study (13Yu Q. Pecchia D.B. Kingsley S.L. Heckman J.E. Burke J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 23524-23533Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Furthermore, the elucidation of the structural basis for the strong guanosine requirement at the cleavage site may pave the way for the development of hairpin ribozymes that target previously inaccessible sequences (30Pinard R. Lambert D. Walter N.G. Heckman J.E. Major F. Burke J.M. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 16035-16039Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Experimental tools to deal with each of these limitations to antiviral activity appear to be at hand. It is likely that significantly higher levels of antiviral activity can be achieved by engineering ribozyme expression constructs that are transcribed more efficiently, are preferentially transported to and retained within the cytoplasm, and have a greater intracellular half-life. Therefore, we believe that our results are highly encouraging for the development of ribozymes as agents for the selective inactivation of targeted viral and cellular RNA molecules and that experimental gene therapy protocols to prevent or attenuate viral infections are a realistic goal in the foreseeable future. In addition, we thank Scott Tighe from the Vermont Cancer Center Flow Cytometry Facility for data analysis.
